journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Transient free-convective flow through a vertical porous annulus

article-meta.aff: Department of Mathematics, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mathematics, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria. email: olubadey2k@yahoo.com

abstract.p: A numerical study is reported to investigate the transient free-convective flow through a vertical porous annulus. A closed-form solution is also presented for temperature, velocity, skin friction, and rate of heat transfer for the steady fully developed flow. During the course of numerical computation, an excellent agreement was found between steady state solutions with transient solutions at large values of time. It is also seen that steady state temperature and velocity are independent of Prandtl number in the absence of suction/injection, while dependent on Prandtl number in the presence of suction/injection.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Natural convection in a vertical porous channel has been extensively studied due to its wide variety of technological applications in areas of engineering. These applications includes: rocket nozzles, cooling of nuclear reactors, high sinks in turbine blades, high-speed aircrafts and their atmospheric re-entry, chemical devices and process equipment, formation and dispersion of fog, distribution of temperature and moisture over agricultural field and groves of fruit trees, damage of crops due to freezing and pollution of the environment, and so on. Although heat transfer phenomena within such channel is as a result of turbulent forced convection, however, during shut down periods, a study of laminar free convection may provide the sole means of the necessary cooling.

Several investigators have studied the fully developed laminar free convective flows in vertical porous annuli. In the numerical work on the problem of flow in a porous pipe, Berman [1] revealed a multiplicity of solutions for certain ranges of suction velocity, and established that at a certain critical suction rate, the velocity gradient becomes zero. He also pointed out that, for the circular tube geometry, suction could induce a transition to turbulence. Terril and Thomas [2] have shown that the solutions exhibit a marked instability with no solutions obtainable for some values of the suction. El-Shaarawi and Sarhan [3] considered the fully developed free-convection flows in vertical annuli with one isothermal boundary and an opposite adiabatic boundary. Joshi [4] studied the fully developed free-convection flows in vertical annuli with two isothermal boundaries. El-Shaarawi and Al-Nimr [5] investigated the effects of four fundamental boundary conditions by obtaining corresponding fundamental solutions. These four boundary conditions are obtained by combining each of the two conditions of having one boundary maintained at uniform heat flux or at uniform wall temperature with each of the conditions that the opposite boundary is kept isothermal at the inlet fluid temperature or adiabatic.

The significance of suction/injection on the boundary layer control in the field of aerodynamics and space science is well recognized [6]. In another article, Ishak et al. [7] showed that suction/injection of a fluid through the bounding surface as for example in mass transfer cooling, can significantly change the flow field and, as a consequence, affect the heat transfer rate from the plate.

In another article, Alsanea [8] pointed out that in general, suction tends to increase the skin friction and heat transfer coefficient whereas injection acts in the opposite manner. This is well explored by Shojaeford et al. [9], where suction/injection were used to control fluid flow on the surface of subsonic aircraft. Recently, Jha and Ajibade [10] considered the case of a free convective flow of heat generating/absorbing fluid between vertical parallel porous plates due to periodic heating on the porous plates.

The objective of this study is to investigate the transient free-convective flow through a vertical porous annulus when thermal boundary conditions at the outer surface of the inner cylinder is maintained at a constant temperature or at a constant heat flux, while the inner surface of the outer cylinder is at an ambient temperature.

sec.title: 2 GOVERNING EQUATIONS
sec.p:
This study considers transient free-convective fully developed fluid flow through a vertical porous annulus. The vertical porous annulus considered is of infinite length. The z'-axis is taken along the axis of the cylinder in the vertical upward direction and r'-axis is in the radial direction. The radii of the inner and outer cylinders are aandb, respectively. Initially, the temperature of both cylinders and of the fluid is assumed to be T0. At time t'>0, the outer surface of inner porous cylinder is heated or cooled either isothermally or at a constant heat flux, whereas temperature at the inner surface of the outer porous cylinder is kept at T0. The buoyancy force arising from the temperature gradient due to asymmetric thermal boundary conditions causes the transient motion of the fluid. Further, it is assumed that suction/injection are of the form v0ar'. A schematic diagram of the problem is shown in Fig. 1. Since the flow is fully developed and cylinders are of infinite length, the flow depends only on radial co-ordinate (r') and time (t'). Thus, under the usual Boussinesq approximation, the basic mathematical models relevant to the present physical situation are (1) (2) Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of the problem
The initial and boundary conditions relevant to the present problem are (3)

It is worthwhile to mention here that analytical solutions of such a mathematical model are applicable to computational fluid dynamics code calibration for three dimensional time dependent natural convection flow in an annulus having thermal boundary conditions of the first kind (Dirichlet conditions) and second kind (Neumann conditions).

Furthermore, it is known that unsteady laminar free-convection flow in a porous annulus has its applications in technological processes such as early stages of melting and in transient heating of insulating air gaps by heat input at the start-up of furnaces. In addition, unsteady laminar free-convection flow is likely to find wider use as it could provide the flow mechanism in some types of solar heating and ventilating passive systems.
The results obtained in this study would enhance the comprehension of flow mechanism in unsteady free-convection flow in annulus for different physical situations.
The above equations are rendered in non-dimensional form by using the following non-dimensional parameters (4)
Here ÎTisTw'-T0orq'aÎº according as inner cylinder is maintained at constant temperature Tw' or constant heat flux q', respectively.
All the physical quantities used in the above expressions are defined in notation. Usingequation (4) in equations (1) to (3), the dimensionless momentum and energy equations are (5) (6)

sec.title: 3 ANALYTICAL SOLUTIONS
sec.p: The governing equations presented in the previous section are difficult to solve and exhibit no closed-form solutions. In general, such solutions can be used in validating computer routines of complex problems and comparison with experimental data. It is, therefore, of interest to reduce the governing equations of the present problem to a form that can be solved in closed-form. A special case of the present problem that exhibits exact or closed-form solution is the problem of steady free-convection flow through a vertical porous annulus. The momentum and energy equations for this special problem can be written as (8) (9)
Subject to the boundary conditions (10)

A unified solution for both isothermal and constant heat flux cases at the outer surface of inner porous cylinder can be obtained by combining both conditions for temperature field at the inner cylinder. By doing so, combined condition is obtained as
In which suitable values to A, B, and C give the corresponding case of either isothermal heating or constant heat flux of the inner cylinder.

The closed-form solutions, which are obtained by solving the differential equations (8) and (9) under the boundary conditions (10) are (11) (12) where
and
By the use ofequation (12) the skin frictions at the cylinder walls are
Also, the rate of heat transfer expressed as Nusselt numbers at the cylinder walls are

sec.title: 4 NUMERICAL SOLUTIONS
sec.p: The method employed here for solving numerically the governing equations (5) and (6) along with the initial and boundary conditions (7) is the implicit finite difference method. The procedure involves discretization of the transport equations (5) and (6) into finite difference equations at the grid point (i,j). Here, the index i refers to R and j to t. The time derivative is replaced by the backward difference formula, while spatial derivative is replaced by the central difference formula. The resulting system of linear algebraic equations is tri-diagonal. The system of algebraic equations after some algebraic manipulations in the tri-diagonal form is solved by using the Thomas algorithm.

In each time step, the temperature field has been solved first, and then the velocity field is evaluated using the already known values of the temperature field. The process of computation is advanced until a steady state is approached by satisfying the following convergence criterion
with respect to temperature and velocity fields. Here Ai,j stands for the velocity and temperature fields, M the number of interior grid points, and |A|max the maximum absolute value of Ai,j.

The closed-form solutions reported in the previous section are used as a check on the accuracy and effectiveness of the numerical procedure. For large values of time, a steady state condition is reached. This corresponds to the steady state version of the problem considered in the previous section.

sec.title: 5 DISCUSSION OF THE RESULTS
sec.p: The main results of the numerical simulation as well as the closed-form solutions are given and discussed. The present problem is governed by the parameters Pr (Prandtl number), Î» (ratio of the radius of outer cylinder to that of the inner cylinder), S (suction/injection), and time (t).

To examine the effect of these controlling parameters, the variations of temperature and velocity fields are presented in Figs 2 to 10. It is observed that the velocity and temperature fields are time dependent. They become steady for large values of the non-dimensional time. Fig. 2
Transient temperature profiles for different values of Pr (isothermal case)

Figures 2 and 3 depict the transient temperature profiles of air (Pr=0.71) and sulphur dioxide (Pr=2.0) for isothermal and isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder, whereas Fig. 4 shows the steady state temperature profiles for isothermal and constant heat flux at outer surface of inner cylinder. From Figs 2 and 3, it is observed that the transient temperature increases with increase in time (t) for isothermal as well as isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. Furthermore, Figs 2 and 3 reveal that the transient temperature decreases with the increase of Pr for isothermal as well as isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. This is the usual trend which is attributed to reduced thermal diffusivity at high-value of Pr. It is interesting to note that the effect of Pr is just reversed on steady state temperature profiles as observed in Fig. 4. In addition, from Fig. 4, it is evident that time required to reach steady state increases as the values of Pr increases. Also, time required to reach steady state is higher for the isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder in comparison to isothermal heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. Fig. 3
Transient temperature profiles for different values of Pr (constant heat flux case) Fig. 4
Steady state temperature profiles for different values of Pr (isothermal and constant heat flux cases)

Figures 5 and 6 show the transient velocity profiles of air (Pr=0.71) and sulphur dioxide (Pr=2.0) for isothermal and constant heat flux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder, whereas Fig. 7 shows the steady state velocity profiles for isothermal as well as constant heat flux at outer surface of inner cylinder. An obvious fact in Figs 5 and 6 is that the velocity profiles are time dependent and increases with increase in time (t) for both isothermal and isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. Also, Figs 5 and 6 reveal that the transient velocity decreases with the increase of Pr. This is physically true because as Pr increases temperature decreases causing weak-convection current. From Fig. 7, it is obvious that the steady state velocity profiles increases with increase of Pr. This suggests that the time required for the velocity to reach steady state is higher for high values of Pr, especially for the isoflux case. Physically, this is true, because an increase in Pr decreases thethermal diffusivity of the working fluid, and hence the temperature decreases, which leads to a decrease in velocity. It is interesting to note that the role of Prandtl number in case of transient temperature and velocity is just contrast to the steady state case. Fig. 5
Transient velocity profiles for different values of Pr (isothermal case) Fig. 6
Transient velocity profiles for different values of Pr (constant heat flux case) Fig. 7
Steady state velocity profiles for different values of Pr (isothermal and constant heat flux cases)

Figure 8 shows the transient (tâ=â0.2) and steady state velocity profiles for different values of suction/injection parameter (S) both for isothermal and isoflux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder when the channel gap is less than or equal to the radius of the inner cylinder (i.eÎ»â¤2). A critical look at this figure reveals that for small values of suction/injection parameter (S=0.5), the steady state velocity in case of constant heat flux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder is less than that of the isothermal heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. As suction/injection parameter (S) increases (S=1.5) with a corresponding increase in channel gap (Î»=2), the steady state velocity is higher in case of constant heat flux in comparison to the isothermal heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. Fig. 8
Transient and steady state velocity profiles for different values of S(Pr=0.71,Î»â¤2)

Figure 9 shows the transient as well as steady state velocity profiles for isothermal and constant heat flux heating of the outer surface of inner cylinder for different values of suction/injection parameter (S) when the channel gap is greater than the radius of the inner cylinder (i.eÎ»>2). From this figure, it is clear that transient velocity profiles are higher in case of isothermal heating in comparison to constant heat flux heating. This shows that convection current is stronger in case of isothermal heating in comparison to isoflux heating in transient state. Also, this figure reveals that convection current is weaker in case of isothermal heating in steady state. Furthermore, as S increases velocity increases. Fig. 9
Transient and steady state velocity profiles for different values of S(Pr=0.71,Î»>2) Fig. 10
Transient and steady state velocity profiles for different values of Pr at a particular section of the annulus

In Fig. 10, the velocity profiles for different values of Pr at a particular fluid section in the annulus (R=1.4,Î»=1.8,S=0.5) are illustrated. It is clear from this figure that the time required to reach steady state condition for constant heat flux heating strongly depends on Prandtl number, while for isothermal heating, the dependence on Prandtl number is negligible.

From Tables 1 and 2, it is observed that transient values Ï1 and ÏÎ» increase with the increase in time for both isothermal and constant heat flux heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. Also, it is evident from Table 1 that transient values Ï1 and ÏÎ» decreases for Pr = 0.71 and increases for Pr = 2.0 with increase in suction/injection parameter (S), while they both decrease with increase in Pr. The steady state Ï1 increases, while steady state ÏÎ» decreases with the increase in suction/injection parameter (S), whereas they both increase with the increase in Pr. In Table 2, transient values Ï1 and ÏÎ» increase as suction/injection parameter (S) increases, while they decrease as Pr increases. Also, steady state values Ï1 and ÏÎ» increase with the increase in suction/injection parameter (S) and decrease as Pr increases. This is physically true because as time increases, transient velocity increases, and hence there is more friction at the walls of the cylinders. At the steady state, it is evident that in the presence of suction/injection, velocity and temperature depend on Prandtl number which is not true in the absence of suction/injection (i.e. velocity and temperature are independent of Prandtl number).

Table 3 presents the numerical values of rate of heat transfer at outer surface of inner cylinder (Nu1) and inner surface of outer cylinder (NuÎ») for isothermal heating of outer surface of inner cylinder. From Table 3, it is observed that as time increases rate of heat transfer increases on the outer surface of inner cylinder as well as inner surface of outer cylinder. This is so because as time increases, the temperature difference between the fluid and the cylinder increases. Furthermore, transient rate of heat transfer at the outer surface of the inner cylinder increases as Pr increases and decreases as suction/injection parameter (S) increases, while steady state rate of heat transfer at the outer surface of the inner cylinder decreases as Pr as well as suction/injection parameter (S) increases. At the inner surface of the outer cylinder, both transient and steady state NuÎ» increases as Pr and suction/injection parameter (S) increases. This is attributed to the fact that the transient temperature difference between the surface of cylinder and fluid decreases as Pr increases, while in the steady state it increases as Pr increases. Variation of Nusselt number at the inner surface of outer cylinder in case of isoflux heating at the outer surface of inner cylinder is presented in Table 4. From this table, it is evident that as suction/injection parameter increases, rate of heat transfer increase, while the result is just reverse for Prandtl number for transient as well as steady state. sec.title: 6 CONCLUSION
sec.p: This article has examined the transient free-convective flow of a viscous incompressible fluid through a vertical porous annulus using the numerical method. A closed-form solution has also been presented for steady state. Results obtained by numerical method show excellent agreement with analytical result at large values of time. It is discovered that in the absence of suction/injection parameter Prandtl number has no effect on the steady state velocity and temperature profiles, while in the presence of suction/injection parameter, steady state velocity and temperature profiles depends on Prandtl number. It is also observed that while Prandtl number decreases the transient temperature and velocity, it increases the steady state temperature and velocity.
